subject: Re: [junit] How to extend our own testcase
msgSnippet: It appears that in our quest to write testable codes, we tend to forget that we are still writing object oriented code and we must adhere to all of the tenets
messageBody:
It appears that in our quest to write testable codes,
we tend to forget that we are still writing object
oriented code and we must adhere to all of the tenets
of this methology, i.e. encapsulation,inheritance and
polymorphyism. We should take advantage of these
features in our test designs as we do in application
designs.

Ernest
--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:

---------------------------------
Chirag Shashikant Doshi wrote:

> Hi all,
>
> I have a Test Case class say BaseTest, There are
some 10 odd tests in
> this class and a few setup methods. The test methods
are bound to the
> setup methods ie. they expected the setup to have
generated some values
> which the test methods use for asserts.
> Now I want to change one particular setup method to
set up the values
> differently so that I can test a different
functionality, here I am
> trying to check if a proper exception is raised. The
approach I trie was
> I made a sub-class of the BaseTest say ExtendedTest
and here I overrided
> one of the setup functions and wrote a single test
method which will
> assert for exception based on the new setup that was
done in the
> ExtendtedTest.
> But when I tried to run the test I found that Junit
execute all the
> tests that belonmg to the superClass testCase too
and here it uses the
> overrdden setup methods and thus in my case all my
super class tests
> fail.
> Is this the expected behavior ? Am I trying the
right thing for my
> problem, is there a cleaner way for my kind of a
requirement ?

Yes, this is the expected behavior. If all Bs are As,
then you probably
want Bs to behave like As; therefore, you create BTest
extends ATest,
and when you execute BTest, you test whether Bs behave
like As by
inheriting the tests from ATest. Makes sense, I think.

If you have two test case classes that want to share a
test fixture
(setup), then extract the setup into an abstract
subclass of TestCase
(called, say, TestFixture) and have the two test case
classes extend
TestFixture rather than TestCase.

Also remember: if your TestCase adds /more/ test
fixture, be sure to
invoke super.setUp()!
